title: Falling sales write off e-readers
text:
Welcome to your preview of The Times Subscribe now Falling sales write off e-readers Sales of paper and hardback books are rising for the first time in eight years - and sales of Kindles are falling Karly Domb Sadof/Associated Press Google+ 1 of 1 Sales of paper and hardback books are rising for the first time in eight years - and sales of Kindles are falling Karly Domb Sadof/Associated Press Kaya Burgess Published 1 minute ago 
Reports of the death of printed books are, as Mark Twain may have put it, greatly exaggerated. Sales of ink-and-paper editions have risen for the first time since 2007 and Waterstones is now removing Kindle e-readers from its shelves because of “pitiful” sales. 
The news will come as a filip to the publishing industry on “Super Thursday”, when bookshops will be flooded with 503 new hardbacks — twice as many as in an average week and 300 more than the following Thursday. 
The advent of ebooks has long been taken as a death knell for print, but sales of paper and Subscribe now
